derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English: from Old English lynis (in the sense 'linchpin') + pin

entry.tran: 关键；关键性人物（或事物）
entry.def: If you refer to a person or thing as the linchpin of something, you mean that they are the most important person or thing involved in it.

example.ex: He's  the lynchpin of our team and crucial to my long-term plans.
example.tran: 他是我们队伍的核心，对实现我的长远规划举足轻重。

means.word_mean: 1. a central cohesive source of support and stability;

sentences.sentence: "the keystone of campaign reform was the ban on soft money"
"he is the linchpin of this firm"

means.word_mean: 2. pin inserted through an axletree to hold a wheel on
